Sentence: Jack is delighted to discover that Gwendolen returns his (Jack) affections, but he (Jack) is alarmed to learn that Gwendolen is fixated on the name Ernest, which she (Cecily) says ', "``inspires absolute confidence
(she)', 'Gwendolen makes clear that she (Cecily) would not consider marrying a man who was not named Ernest

Algernon is less enchanted to learn that part of Cecily's interest in him (Jack) derives from the name Ernest, which, unconsciously echoing Gwendolen, she (Cecily) says ', "``inspires absolute confidence
Gwendolen points out that this is impossible as she (Cecily) herself is engaged to Ernest Worthing
However, when Jack and Algernon tell Gwendolen and Cecily that they have both made arrangements to be christened Ernest that afternoon, all is forgiven and the two pairs of lovers embrace
